strings.Name: Introduction
strings.value: I am always looking for opportunities to build cool things and learn new and progressive technologies. I am especially interested in the gaming industry and roles that allow me to be creative.

workExperience.Name: Rivian Automotive
workExperience.Description:
I interviewed, onboarded, and joined Rivian remotely at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. This was my first time at a large tech company and I had many more engineers to collaborate with and mentor. 

I worked on a breadth of projects as lead engineer and I could make a consistent impact through the projects I worked on. Whether it was administrating our CMS, writing tools, writing api endpoints, crafting front-ends, terraforming infrastructure, mentoring engineers, giving talks, writing documentation, creating and delegating tickets, or fixing prod issues on-call, I did it all!

Rivian has been an interesting experience. I really got the chance to conduct interviews and work across the stack. Never have I met so many talented engineers in one place.

workExperience.Name: Starcity
workExperience.Description:
After deciding on a whim to try the [triplebyte](https://triplebyte.com) I surprisingly passed the 3% acceptance rate and was a certified front-end engineer. I skipped to the final round with 5 companies out in Silicon valley and ended up at Starcity. 

I also decided to test out the experience of coliving and live in one of Starcity's buildings. I really enjoyed the experience and I learned a lot about full stack work and leadership. 

I eventually became the tech lead for the growth team and I spent a lot of my time documenting and delegating work to my team of engineers. I also learned a lot about marketing and analytics as well as the technologies surrounding it.

workExperience.Name: Sportshub Technologies
workExperience.Description:
Sports Technologies Inc became Sportshub Technologies when they merged with another group from the midwest. Though I kept my position in CT working on fantasy games for clients, our own company had started development on a daily fantasy app.

I had began to be the primary front-end developer on many fantasy games and was eventually called to be the lead engineer of our internal daily fantasy app. I lead the front end development in Minneapolis throughout the summer of 2018 until we launched for NFL kickoff.

I really got the chance to learn from engineers outside of our bubble in CT. I learned a lot about best engineering practices like code reviewing, testing, as well as new technologies like kubernetes and Jenkins.

workExperience.Name: Sports Technologies Inc
workExperience.Description:
I started my journey at Sportstech as a contractor and did general front end maintenance work in a few of the smaller fantasy games that weren't in season. I soon graduated into making pseudo single page apps with rails and jQuery. 

Eventually moving onto making single page apps. These apps came in the form of fantasy sports games which were built with mostly Angular 1.x, eventually Angular 2 and React. I learned the necessary skills to make responsive and fun sports fantasy experiences.

I worked alongside many sports organization clients such as the NCAA, NFL, NHL, PGA and many more. I learned how to operate apps at scale by leveraging different kinds of caching and performing QA on all kinds of devices and browsers.

workExperience.Name: Robert Half (Moonbase3)
workExperience.Description: Quick contracting gig instrumented by Robert Half to a local website business by the name of Moonbase3 out of East Hartford. I worked on websites for local businesses and Wordpress plugins for existing customers.

workExperience.Name: ITS Spiders
workExperience.Description:
I started my career as a web developer for the IT department at Syracuse University. I made websites for the university. I stumbled upon a general job posting on the syracuse subreddit of all places and quickly found myself in the interview seat. 

> How long would it take you to learn a new language?

"I don't know two weeks maybe?"
And I was off learning PHP. Alongside the web basics of HTML/CSS/JS but also Wordpress. I worked here from the beginning to the end of my time at Syracuse. I stayed through the summer to continue working that job. I learned much more at my job than I ever did at any classroom at Syracuse, so I decided to leave and continue to web development full time.

technologyExperience.Extra: Familiar with writing own configs as well as exending and fixing existing configs
technologyExperience.Name: Webpack

technologyExperience.Extra: Putting this here for posterity, I don't want to work with PHP if I can help it.
technologyExperience.Name: PHP + Wordpress

technologyExperience.Extra: Experienced with: CircleCI, Gitlab CI, Github Actions, Jenkins
technologyExperience.Name: CI/CD

technologyExperience.Extra: Lambda, Cloudwatch, S3, Cloudfront, EC2, ECS, ECR, Opensearch, DynamoDB, Secrets Manager
technologyExperience.Name: AWS
